entities.description: John Montagu, 4th Earl of Sandwich, PC, FRS was a British statesman who succeeded his grandfather Edward Montagu, 3rd Earl of Sandwich as the Earl of Sandwich in 1729, at the age of ten. During his life, he held various military and political offices, including Postmaster General, First Lord of the Admiralty, and Secretary of State for the Northern Department. He is also known for the claim that h

entities.title: Secretary of State for the Northern Department
entities.description: The Secretary of State for the Northern Department was a position in the Cabinet of the government of Great Britain up to 1782, when the Northern Department became the Foreign Office.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean-Jacques Barthélemy, French archaeologist and author (b. 1716)

entities.title: Jean-Jacques Barthélemy
entities.description: Jean-Jacques Barthélemy was a French scholar who became the first person to decipher an extinct language. He deciphered the Palmyrene alphabet in 1754 and the Phoenician alphabet in 1758.

heading: Deaths
txt: Onogawa Kisaburō, Japanese sumo wrestler, the 5th Yokozuna (b. 1758)

entities.title: Onogawa Kisaburō
entities.description: Onogawa Kisaburō  was a Japanese sumo wrestler from Ōmi Province. He was the sport's 5th yokozuna. Along with Tanikaze, Onogawa was the first to be given a yokozuna licence by the House of Yoshida Tsukasa and the first to perform the dohyō-iri to promote sumo tournaments. His real name was Kawamura Kisaburō

entities.title: Makuuchi
entities.description: Makuuchi (幕内), or makunouchi (幕の内), is the top division of the six divisions of professional sumo. Its size is fixed at 42 wrestlers (rikishi), ordered into five ranks according to their ability as defined by their performance in previous tournaments.

heading: Deaths
txt: Peter Andreas Heiberg, Danish philologist and author (b. 1758)

entities.title: Peter Andreas Heiberg
entities.description: Peter Andreas Heiberg was a Danish-Norwegian author and philologist. He was born in Vordingborg, Denmark-Norway. The Heiberg ancestry can be traced back to Norway, and has produced a long line of priests, headmasters and other learned men. Peter Andreas Heibergs father was the Norwegian-born headmaster of the grammar school in Vordingborg, Ludvig Heiberg, while his mother was Inger Margrethe, daug

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles, Austrian commander and duke of Teschen (b. 1771)

entities.title: Archduke Charles, Duke of Teschen
entities.description: Archduke Charles Louis John Joseph Laurentius of Austria, Duke of Teschen was an Austrian field-marshal, the third son of Emperor Leopold II and his wife, Maria Luisa of Spain. He was also the younger brother of Francis II, Holy Roman Emperor. Despite being epileptic, Charles achieved respect both as a commander and as a reformer of the Austrian army. He was considered one of Napoleon's more formi

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean Danjou, French captain (b. 1828)

entities.title: Jean Danjou
entities.description: Jean Danjou was a decorated captain in the French Foreign Legion. He commanded the two lieutenants and 62 legionnaires who fought the legendary Battle of Camarón during the French intervention in Mexico, during which he was killed.

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert FitzRoy, English admiral, meteorologist, and politician, 2nd Governor of New Zealand (b. 1805)

entities.title: Robert FitzRoy
entities.description: Vice-Admiral Robert FitzRoy was an English officer of the Royal Navy and a scientist. He achieved lasting fame as the captain of HMS Beagle during Charles Darwin's famous voyage, FitzRoy's second expedition to Tierra del Fuego and the Southern Cone.

entities.title: Governor of New Zealand
entities.description: The governor-general of New Zealand is the viceregal representative of the monarch of New Zealand, currently Queen Elizabeth II. As the Queen is concurrently the monarch of 15 other Commonwealth realms, and lives in the United Kingdom, she, on the advice of her New Zealand prime minister, appoints a governor-general to carry out her constitutional and ceremonial duties within the Realm of New Zeal

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Cooke, Canadian bishop and missionary (b. 1792)

entities.title: Thomas Cooke (bishop)
entities.description: Thomas Cooke was a Canadian Roman Catholic priest, missionary, and the first Bishop of Trois Rivières from 1852 to 1870.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean-Frédéric Waldeck, French explorer, lithographer, and cartographer (b. 1766)

entities.title: Jean-Frédéric Waldeck
entities.description: Jean-Frédéric Maximilien de Waldeck was a French antiquarian, cartographer, artist and explorer. He was a man of talent and accomplishment, but his love of self-promotion and refusal to let the truth get in the way of a good story leave some aspects of his life in mystery.

heading: Deaths
txt: Emma Smith, American religious leader (b. 1804)

entities.title: Emma Smith
entities.description: Emma Hale Smith Bidamon was the first wife of Joseph Smith and a leader in the early days of the Latter Day Saint movement, both during Joseph's lifetime and afterward as a member of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints. In 1842, when the Ladies' Relief Society of Nauvoo was formed as a women's service organization, she was elected by its members as the organization's first

heading: Deaths
txt: Édouard Manet, French painter (b. 1832)

entities.title: Édouard Manet
entities.description: Édouard Manet was a French modernist painter. He was one of the first 19th-century artists to paint modern life, and a pivotal figure in the transition from Realism to Impressionism.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joseph Leidy, American paleontologist and author (b. 1823)

entities.title: Joseph Leidy
entities.description: Joseph Mellick Leidy was an American paleontologist, parasitologist and anatomist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Casey Jones, American railroad engineer (b. 1863)

entities.title: Casey Jones
entities.description: John Luther "Casey" Jones was an American railroader who was killed when his passenger train collided with a stalled freight train at Vaughan, Mississippi.

heading: Deaths
txt: Emily Stowe, Canadian physician and activist (b. 1831)

entities.title: Emily Stowe
entities.description: Emily Howarde Stowe was the first female physician to practise in Canada, the second licensed female physician in Canada and an activist for women's rights and suffrage. Stowe helped found the women's suffrage movement in Canada and campaigned for the country's first medical college for women.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean Moréas, Greek poet and critic (b. 1856)

entities.title: Jean Moréas
entities.description: Jean Moréas, was a Greek poet, essayist, and art critic, who wrote mostly in the French language but also in Greek during his youth.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bessie Coleman, American pilot (b. 1892)

entities.title: Bessie Coleman
entities.description: Bessie Coleman was an early American civil aviator. She was the first African-American woman and first Native-American to hold a pilot license. She earned her pilot license from the Fédération Aéronautique Internationale on June 15, 1921, and was the first black person to earn an international pilot's license.

heading: Deaths
txt: A. E. Housman, English poet and scholar (b. 1859)

entities.title: A. E. Housman
entities.description: Alfred Edward Housman, usually known as A. E. Housman, was an English classical scholar and poet. His cycle of poems, A Shropshire Lad wistfully evoke the dooms and disappointments of youth in the English countryside. Their simplicity and distinctive imagery appealed strongly to Edwardian taste, and to many early 20th-century English composers both before and after the First World War. Through the

heading: Deaths
txt: Frank Haller, American boxer (b. 1883)

entities.title: Frank Haller
entities.description: Frank Bee Haller was an American featherweight professional boxer who competed in the early twentieth century. He won a silver medal in Boxing at the 1904 Summer Olympics, beating fellow American Frederick Gilmore, but losing to Oliver Kirk in the final.

heading: Deaths
txt: Eddy Hamel, American footballer (b. 1902)

entities.title: Eddy Hamel
entities.description: Eddy Hamel was an American soccer player for Dutch club AFC Ajax. Hamel was the first Jewish player for Ajax. He was killed by the Nazis in 1943 in Auschwitz concentration camp.

heading: Deaths
txt: Otto Jespersen, Danish linguist and academic (b. 1860)

heading: Deaths
txt: Beatrice Webb, English sociologist and economist (b. 1858)

heading: Deaths
txt: Jacob Linzbach, Estonian linguist and author (b. 1874)

entities.title: Jacob Linzbach
entities.description: Jacob Linzbach was an Estonian linguist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alben W. Barkley, American lawyer and politician, 35th Vice President of the United States (b. 1877)

entities.title: Alben W. Barkley
entities.description: Alben William Barkley was an American lawyer and politician from Kentucky who served in both houses of Congress and as the 35th vice president of the United States from 1949 to 1953. In 1905, he was elected county attorney for McCracken County, Kentucky. He was chosen County Judge/Executive in 1909 and U.S. representative from Kentucky's First District in 1912. As a Representative, he was a libera

entities.title: Vice President of the United States
entities.description: The vice president of the United States (VPOTUS) is the second-highest officer in the executive branch of the U.S. federal government, after the president of the United States, and ranks first in the presidential line of succession. The vice president is also an officer in the legislative branch, as the president of the Senate. In this capacity, the vice president is empowered to preside over Sena

heading: Deaths
txt: Jacques Presser, Dutch historian, writer and poet (b. 1899)

entities.title: Jacques Presser
entities.description: Jacob (Jacques) Presser was a Dutch historian, writer and poet, known for his book Ashes in the wind  on the history of the persecution of the Jews in the Netherlands during World War II. Presser made a significant contribution to Dutch historical scholarship, as well as to European historical scholarship.

heading: Deaths
txt: Inger Stevens, Swedish-American actress (b. 1934)

heading: Deaths
txt: Gia Scala, English-American model and actress (b. 1934)

entities.title: Gia Scala
entities.description: Gia Scala was an English born Italian-American actress and model.

heading: Deaths
txt: Václav Renč, Czech poet and playwright (b. 1911)

entities.title: Václav Renč
entities.description: Václav Renč was a Czech poet, dramatist and translator. Like other Catholic ruralistic writers, his themes included God, traditions and the countryside.

heading: Deaths
txt: Agnes Moorehead, American actress (b. 1900)

entities.title: Agnes Moorehead
entities.description: Agnes Robertson Moorehead was an American actress whose 41-year career included work in radio, stage, film, and television. She is best known for her role as Endora on the television series Bewitched, but she also had notable roles in films, including Citizen Kane, The Magnificent Ambersons, Dark Passage, All That Heaven Allows, Show Boat, and Hush...Hush, Sweet Charlotte.

heading: Deaths
txt: Luis Muñoz Marín, Puerto Rican journalist and politician, 1st Governor of Puerto Rico (b. 1898)

entities.title: Luis Muñoz Marín
entities.description: José Luis Alberto Muñoz Marín was a Puerto Rican journalist, politician, statesman and was the first elected governor of Puerto Rico, regarded as the "Architect of the Puerto Rico Commonwealth."

entities.title: Governor of Puerto Rico
entities.description: The Governor of Puerto Rico is the highest executive authority of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, its head of state, head of government, and commander-in-chief of the Puerto Rico National Guard.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lester Bangs, American journalist and author (b. 1949)

entities.title: Lester Bangs
entities.description: Leslie Conway "Lester" Bangs was an American music journalist, critic, author, and musician. He wrote for Creem and Rolling Stone magazines, and was known for his leading influence in rock music criticism. The music critic Jim DeRogatis called him "America's greatest rock critic".

heading: Deaths
txt: George Balanchine, Russian dancer and choreographer (b. 1904)

entities.title: George Balanchine
entities.description: George Balanchine was an American ballet choreographer who was one of the most influential 20th-century choreographers. Styled as the father of American ballet, he co-founded the New York City Ballet and remained its Artistic Director for more than 35 years. His choreography is characterized by plotless ballets with minimal costume and décor, performed to classical and neoclassical music.

heading: Deaths
txt: Muddy Waters, American singer-songwriter, guitarist, and bandleader (b. 1913)

heading: Deaths
txt: Edouard Wyss-Dunant, Swiss physician and mountaineer (b. 1897)

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert Stevenson, English director, producer, and screenwriter (b. 1905)

entities.title: Robert Stevenson (director)
entities.description: Robert Edward Stevenson was an English film screenwriter, director and actor.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sergio Leone, Italian director, producer, and screenwriter (b. 1929)

entities.title: Sergio Leone
entities.description: Sergio Leone was an Italian film director, producer and screenwriter, credited as the creator of the Spaghetti Western genre and widely regarded as one of the most influential directors in the history of cinema.

heading: Deaths
txt: Tommy Caton, English footballer (b. 1962)

entities.title: Tommy Caton
entities.description: Thomas Stephen Caton was an English footballer who played as a centre half for Manchester City, Arsenal, Oxford United and Charlton Athletic. Caton captained both Manchester City and Oxford United and was named as City's Player of the Year in 1982.

heading: Deaths
txt: Roland Ratzenberger, Austrian race car driver (b. 1960)

entities.title: Roland Ratzenberger
entities.description: Roland Ratzenberger was an Austrian racing driver who raced in sports prototype, British Formula 3000, Japanese Formula 3000 and Formula One. He died in a crash during qualifying for the 1994 San Marino Grand Prix, the same event at which three-time World Champion Ayrton Senna died the following day. As a direct result of his death, the Grand Prix Drivers' Association was reformed.

heading: Deaths
txt: Richard Scarry, American author and illustrator (b. 1919)

heading: Deaths
txt: Maung Maung Kha, Burmese colonel and politician, 8th Prime Minister of Burma (b. 1920)

entities.title: Maung Maung Kha
entities.description: Maung Maung Kha was the 8th Prime Minister of Burma between 1977 and 1988.

entities.title: Prime Minister of Burma
entities.description: The prime minister of Myanmar was the head of government of Myanmar from 1948 to 2011.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nizar Qabbani, Syrian-English poet, publisher, and diplomat (b. 1926)

entities.title: Nizar Qabbani
entities.description: Nizar Tawfiq Qabbani was a Syrian diplomat, poet, writer and publisher. His poetic style combines simplicity and elegance in exploring themes of love, eroticism, feminism, religion, and Arab nationalism. Qabbani is one of the most revered contemporary poets in the Arab world, and is considered to be Syria's National Poet.

heading: Deaths
txt: Poul Hartling, Danish politician, 36th Prime Minister of Denmark (b. 1914)

entities.title: Poul Hartling
entities.description: Poul Hartling was a Danish politician and diplomat. He was a leader of the Liberal Party and served as Prime Minister of Denmark from 1973 to 1975 in the Cabinet of Poul Hartling.

entities.title: Prime Minister of Denmark
entities.description: The prime minister of Denmark is the head of government in the Kingdom of Denmark comprising the three constituent countries: Denmark, Greenland and the Faroe Islands. Before the creation of the modern office, the kingdom did not initially have a head of government separate from its head of state, namely the monarch, in whom the executive authority was vested. The Constitution of 1849 established

heading: Deaths
txt: Charlotte von Mahlsdorf, German philanthropist, founded the Gründerzeit Museum (b. 1928)

entities.title: Charlotte von Mahlsdorf
entities.description: Charlotte von Mahlsdorf was a transgender woman who founded the Gründerzeit Museum in Berlin-Mahlsdorf.

entities.title: Gründerzeit
entities.description: Gründerzeit was the economic phase in 19th-century Germany and Austria before the great stock market crash of 1873. In Central Europe, the age of industrialisation had been taking place since the 1840s. That period is not precisely dated, but in Austria, the March Revolution of 1848 is generally accepted as the beginning of economic changes, in contrast to political reforms. "Weimarisierung" is an

heading: Deaths
txt: Mark Berger, American economist and academic (b. 1955)

entities.title: Mark Berger (economist)
entities.description: Professor Mark C. Berger, was the director of The Center for Business and Economic Research at the University of Kentucky until his death at age 47. He was also a Fulbright Scholar at University College Dublin. Originally hailing from Sylvania, Ohio, Berger earned his BA from the University of Toledo and his MA and PhD from The Ohio State University.

heading: Deaths
txt: Possum Bourne, New Zealand race car driver (b. 1956)

heading: Deaths
txt: Phil Rasmussen, American lieutenant and pilot (b. 1918)

entities.title: Phil Rasmussen
entities.description: Philip M. Rasmussen was an Army Air Corps second lieutenant assigned to the 46th Pursuit Squadron at Wheeler Field on the island of Oahu during the Japanese attack on December 7, 1941. He was one of the few American pilots to get into the air that day.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean-François Revel, French philosopher (b. 1924)

entities.title: Jean-François Revel
entities.description: Jean-François Revel was a French journalist, philosopher, and a member of the Académie française from June 1998 onwards. A socialist in his youth, Revel later became a prominent European proponent of classical liberalism and free market economics.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pramoedya Ananta Toer, Indonesian author and academic (b. 1925)

heading: Deaths
txt: Kevin Mitchell, American football player (b. 1971)

entities.title: Kevin Mitchell (linebacker)
entities.description: Kevin Danyelle Mitchell was an American football linebacker in the National Football League from Harrisburg, Pennsylvania. He played for the San Francisco 49ers, the New Orleans Saints, and the Washington Redskins.

heading: Deaths
txt: Tom Poston, American actor, comedian, and game show panelist (b. 1921)

heading: Deaths
txt: Gordon Scott, American film and television actor (b. 1926)

heading: Deaths
txt: Juancho Evertsz, Dutch Antillean politician (b. 1923)

entities.title: Juancho Evertsz
entities.description: Juancho Evertsz, whose full name was Juan Miguel Gregorio Evertsz, was a Dutch Antillean politician who served as the Prime Minister of the Netherlands Antilles between 1973 and 1977.

heading: Deaths
txt: Henk Nijdam, Dutch cyclist (b. 1935)

entities.title: Henk Nijdam
entities.description: Henk Nijdam was a Dutch road and track cyclist. His sporting career began with Fortuna Zundert. On track, he finished in fifth place in the 4 km team pursuit at the 1960 Summer Olympics. He also won a gold and a bronze medals in the individual pursuit at world championships in 1962 and 1963.

heading: Deaths
txt: Dorjee Khandu, Indian politician, 6th Chief Minister of Arunachal Pradesh (b. 1955)

entities.title: Dorjee Khandu
entities.description: Dorjee Khandu was an Indian politician who served as Chief Minister of Arunachal Pradesh. He was re elected in 2009 Arunachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly elections.

entities.title: Chief Minister of Arunachal Pradesh
entities.description: The Chief Minister of Arunachal Pradesh is the chief executive of the Indian state of Arunachal Pradesh. As per the Constitution of India, the Governor of Arunachal Pradesh is the state's de jure head, but de facto executive authority rests with the chief minister. Following elections to the Arunachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly, the governor usually invites the party with a majority of seats to

heading: Deaths
txt: Evald Okas, Estonian painter (b. 1915)

heading: Deaths
txt: Ernesto Sabato, Argentinian physicist, author, and painter (b. 1911)

heading: Deaths
txt: Tomás Borge, Nicaraguan poet and politician, co-founded the Sandinista National Liberation Front (b. 1930)

entities.title: Tomás Borge
entities.description: Tomás Borge Martínez was a cofounder of the Sandinista National Liberation Front in Nicaragua and was Interior Minister of Nicaragua during one of the administrations of Daniel Ortega. He was also a renowned statesman, writer, and politician. Tomás Borge also held the titles of "Vice-Secretary and President of the FSLN", member of the Nicaraguan Parliament and National Congress, and Ambassador to

entities.title: Sandinista National Liberation Front
entities.description: The Sandinista National Liberation Front is a socialist political party in Nicaragua. Its members are called Sandinistas [sandiˈnistas] in both English and Spanish. The party is named after Augusto César Sandino, who led the Nicaraguan resistance against the United States occupation of Nicaragua in the 1930s.

entities.title: Roberto Chabet
entities.description: Roberto "Bobby" Rodríguez Chabet was an artist from the Philippines and widely acknowledged as the father of Philippine conceptual art.

heading: Deaths
txt: Khaled Choudhury, Indian painter and set designer (b. 1919)

entities.title: Khaled Choudhury
entities.description: Khaled Choudhury was a theatre personality and artist of Bengal. He worked for various directors of both Bengali and Hindi plays, including Sombhu Mitra, Tripti Mitra, and Shyamanand Jalan in various capacities — creating the Stage, sets and costumes and later as Music Director. He was a bachelor. He has been awarded the Padma Bhushan for his contribution to theatre in India's Republic Day Honours

entities.description: Benjamin Earl King was an American soul and R&B singer and record producer. He is best known as the singer and co-composer of "Stand by Me"—a U.S. Top 10 hit, both in 1961 and later in 1986, a number one hit in the United Kingdom in 1987, and number 25 on the RIAA's list of Songs of the Century—and as one of the principal lead singers of the R&B vocal group The Drifters, notably singing the lead v

heading: Deaths
txt: Daniel Berrigan, American priest and activist (b. 1921)

entities.title: Daniel Berrigan
entities.description: Daniel Joseph Berrigan was an American Jesuit priest, anti-war activist, Christian pacifist, playwright, poet, and author.

txt: Harry Kroto, English chemist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1939)

entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry is awarded annually by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences to scientists in the various fields of chemistry. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895, awarded for outstanding contributions in chemistry, physics, literature, peace, and physiology or medicine. heading: Deaths
txt: Peter Mayhew, English-American actor (b. 1944)

entities.title: Peter Mayhew
entities.description: Peter William Mayhew was an English-American actor, best known for portraying Chewbacca in the Star Wars film series. He played the character in all of his live-action appearances from the 1977 original to 2015's The Force Awakens before his retirement from the role.

heading: Deaths
txt: Tony Allen, Nigerian drummer and composer (b. 1940)

entities.title: Tony Allen (musician)
entities.description: Tony Oladipo Allen was a Nigerian drummer, composer, and songwriter who lived and worked in Paris, France. Allen was the drummer and musical director of Fela Kuti's band Africa '70 from 1968 to 1979, and was one of the primary co-founders of the genre of Afrobeat music.
